title: Julian Hodge Bank and Virgin Money launch market-leading cash Isas
text:
Print 
Julian Hodge Bank's five-year deal and Virgin Money's three-year grab top spots 
Welsh bank Julian Hodge has increased the rates across its one, two and five-year fixed-rate cash Isas and savings bonds. 
The improvements have propelled its five-year Isa to the top of the best-buy tables, dislodging Virgin Money. Its five-year Isa pays 2.55pc, up from 2.4pc, beating Virgin’s 2.51pc. 
Virgin has, however, claimed top spot for three-year Isas. It launched a new account today which pays 2.25pc. This puts Skipton's 2.1pc offer into second place. 
The new one and two-year Isas from Julian Hodge are also competitively priced, matching the best rates on the market, paying 1.75pc, up from 1.6pc, and 2pc, up from 1.8pc, respectively. 
These accounts must be opened by post, while the minimum investment stands at £5,000. Transfers in from previous years' Isas are accepted. 
The bonds pay the same rates, but the minimum investment is lower at £1,000. 
= Verdict = 
The Julian Hodge Bank bonds are some way off the best-buys . Paragon Bank has the best accounts over one (2.07pc), two (2.34pc), three (2.66pc) and five years (3.06pc). While, the top-paying four-year fixed-rate bond from Charter Savings Bank offers 2.75pc . 
• Our pick of the best fixed-rate savings bonds 
The Isa accounts, as mentioned above, are more competitive . 
Susan Hannums, of rate-monitoring site Savingschampion, said: “In recent weeks we have seen some improvements amongst fixed rate ISAs, giving encouragement to those who have yet to use their cash ISA allowance for this tax year, who may have been biding their time in the hope for better deals following an underwhelming Isa season. 
“The current trend in the savings market is for improved fixed-rate deals, this being the latest example and hopefully this will continue with rates being pushed up further as a result.”
